This explanation is the best I've seen so far

I think what's missing for me in these lessons are explanations for what matrices are in practical terms, why do their operations work the way they do, what do different operations actually represent, etc.... These lessons are definitely a huge help, but I'd like to gain an understanding of this that goes beyond just memorizing formulas.  For example, after watching this, I know how to multiply matrices; but I don't know what multiplying matrices achieves in practice or why I'd want to multiply matrices. I also don't know what makes us decide to represent a matrix as a column as opposed to a line (or vice versa). I often start asking myself these sorts of questions very early on during math lessons, and I have trouble paying attention as a result. It's hard to focus on the "how" when you'd really like to know the "why" first. Every rule & formula feels very random and arbitrary when you don't actually know what all of this represents in the real world
Man... I wish this guy was my tutor.. Bless you Professor

thank you so much

Didn't he go over that systems of linear equations can model many real life problems in the first video. Most, if not all(?) of the operations you do to reduce a matrix to echelon form/reduced row echelon form are the same/logical extensions of what you do to solve systems of linear equations not in a matrix. Like substitution, elimination, and the ability to multiply a row or linear equation by a constant. So if you understand those and why they are done, the operations done in a matrix will make sense. (p.s. legitimately correct me if I am wrong)

@meap1022  That explains why the elementary row operations are what they are. But it doesn't explain why matrix multiplication is what it is.   In my opinion, the way to motivate matrix multiplication is to start teaching linear algebra the exact opposite way from how this playlist does it. You start with vectors in space, then talk about linear transformations of space, then develop matrices as efficient ways of encoding the information of a linear transformation, and then define matrix multiplication as corresponding to the composition of linear transformations.  The order in which you decide to cover topics in linear algebra always has trade-offs.

@MuffinsAPlenty  I’m still trying to understand how matrix multiplication doesn’t contradict itself. If I start with a matrix representing 3 linear equations with the variables x, y, and z, I have one column with all x’s, another with all y’s, and another with all z’s. If I have another matrix with 3 linear equations that use the variables u and v, one column has all u’s and the other has all v’s. If I multiply the two systems of equations using matrix multiplication, the first entry has me adding an x*u to a y*u to a z*u, and I assume that I can just add the constant coefficients together. How does that last part not contradict basic algebra? Am I using the wrong matrices to do this?

Or was the point just to say that A and B and C and D must have the same dimensions? But that would be the same conditions as for matrix addition... Couldn't you just say that a matrix operation is distributive if the matrices have the dimensions to fullfill the criteria to do addition and multiplication?

@ProfessorDaveExplains  I put it through MATLAB as well as hand calc and it's coming up as 0 7 -5

(3*1) + (-2*0) + (-1*-3) = 3 + 0 + 3 = 6 (3*9) + (-2*11) + (-1*2) = 27 - 22 - 2 = 3 (3*4) + (-2*5) + (-1*-7) = 12 - 10 + 7 = 9   You're either inputting something incorrectly or using a bogus application.
